resources.string: How to make your own garden:
Making your own garden means you can have a healthy life without spending lots of money\n Even if you only have very little space you can still grow vegetables\n
1. dig the soil to make it loose.
2. Prepare the soil: mix compost with soil add compost in soil and leave it for 8 to 10 days.
4. Soil be prepared in 8 to 10 days
5. Then make a high land for the crops growing.
1. to make compost we need Cow’s urine, leaves , bushes with leaves, ash and Cow dungl.\n \t - make pit according to how much land you have.
2. put layer by layer elements in the pit, firstly, put Bushes with leaves then cow dung, then Urine and ash. repeat until the pit is full.
3. Put a stick that reach the bottom of pit and cover it with Soil.
4. Your compost Pit will be ready in 30 to 35 days.

First make it in 50 liter drum
 It will be useful for all season vegetables and use it by mixing 7 liter of water in 1 liter organic insecticides
 
 collect Sweet , bitter , spicy , sour which have this taste. 
 Like : Garlic , onion , Chilli , bones, Salt.
 
What amount you need according to that you can make it. Like if you need 10 liter then you can add half gram of ingredients with Cow’s urine. 
 
 Put all of ingredients in drum and cover it.
 
 After 4 to 5 days open the drum and move the liquid with a stick.
 
 your Organic Insecticides will be ready to use in 25 to 30 days.

Sarg: It is healthy and easy and grows all year around.
 
 Pumpkin: Rich in vitamin A
 
 Onion: Needed for most foods. Needs frequent watering.
 
 Cauliflower : it helps in Heart disease. It has Choline and Sulforaphane.
 
 Cabbage : It is rich in Vitamin K.
 
 Bitter gourd : It helps in lowering blood pressure.
 
 Tomato : it is rich in Vitamin A and C
 
 Carrot : It is rich in Vitamin A
 
 Cucumber : it is rich in Vitamin K
 
 Eggplant : it is rich in minerals and fibers

To ensure a healthy and nutritional diet, Your meals throughout the day should resemble the picture with the checkmark above.\n Eat at least four types of food every day (including grains and legumes, nuts, vegetables and livestock sources (milk, eggs, fish, meat).
Care should be taken to clean hands, nails and body. \nWash hands thoroughly with soap and water after using the toilet and before eating.

Females differ to the males in that the amount of calories required on a daily basis is lower than their male counterparts. Please follow the amount described below for optimal health-benefits: 
19–30 years ~ 2,000–2,400 calories 
31–59 years ~ 1,800–2,200 calories 
60+ years ~ 1,600–2,000 calories 
Furthermore females should keep prioritize foods which contain Vitamin A and Iron

Vitamin A dense foods:
Green Vegetables: Spinach, Chamsur, Radish Leaf, Beet Munta, Zucchini, Latte, Bethe, Poi Greens etc.
 Fruits and vegetables: ripe mangoes, nuts, carrots, ripe peas, haluwaved etc.
 From the forest and around the water: Neuro, Stinging nettle, Aldo, Simrayo Jaluko etc.
 Animal food: liver, eggs, small fish, milk etc.
Iron dense foods include:\n Green vegetables, Beans (found more in sprouts), Gundruk, Kodo, Beaten rice, Cauliflower leaves Bananas, Meat, Eggs, Fish.\n As well as Food cooked in an iron pot

19–30 years ~ 2,400–3,000 calories 
31–59 years ~ 2,200–3,000 calories 
60+ years ~ 2,000–2,600 calories

Furthermore its common for the average male to be these essential elements: 
Vitamin D, Magnesium, Vitamin B12 and Potassium
 
Vitamin D reduces inflammation and strengthens the skeleton, the vitamin is produced when spending time in the sun but can be supplemented by adding oily fish, meats, eggs and dairy to your diet.
 
Magnesium is another common element is which many males are lacking. Low levels of magnesium may increase your risk of heart disease, magnesium dense foods include: spinach, nuts, seeds and whole grains
 
Vitamin B12 is used for DNA synthesis, energy production, and nerve function. Food sources dense in B12 include: Meats, Fish and dairy products
 
Potassium benefits nerve function and muscle contraction, Potassium rich foods include: Vegetables, milk, yogurt, beans, nuts and fish such as: Tuna, Halibut, Cod and Trout
Pregnant women should eat one more balanced meal than usual.
Regular health check-ups should be done at least 4 times (4, 6, 8, 9 months) and TT vaccination should be done.
After 3 months of pregnancy: go to the health facility and take anti-parasitic medicine.
From the first 3 months of pregnancy to the 45th day after childbirth: one tablet of iron should be taken once.
Get enough rest. You should not work very hard, you should not lift heavy weights and you should rest in between work.
Furthermore children\'s diet should include foods which contain Calcium and Fiber
\nAnother commonly neglected part of a childs diet is ensuring proper hydration, proper hydration improves cognitive function
\n Calcium plays a big part in developing strong, health bones and teeth. Calcium dense foods include: Milk, soy-milk, sardines, cereals and oatmeal
\n Fiber is key to prevent heart disease and other conditions, it also helps digestion and prevents constipation
Limiting snacks is a great way to ensure stable blood sugar
The child should be examined at the health institution on the third day within 24 hours of birth and at 4 months.
The first yellow milk of the mother should be fed as soon as possible (within 1 hour) after the birth of the newborn baby.
From birth to 6 months the baby does not need to be fed water as it is exclusively breast milk.\n Starting breastfeeding as soon as you are born helps to keep the milk constant.\n
Newborns should be breastfed at least 10 times a day, day and night.\n Feed from one breast only after feeding in another way.\n
After the child reaches 6 months and 9 months, go to the health institution for examination

After the completion of 6 months (180 days), breast milk should be fed with different foods till the completion of two years. 
 
 When starting different feeding, feed 2 to 3 tablespoons at a time and then increase to 1 cup of tea (125 ml) at a time.

Different foods should be prepared daily by mixing at least 4 groups of food (grains, nuts, animal foods, fruits and vegetables). \nOnly salt with two children logo should be used when preparing food.
Baby food should be soft and fluffy.
Always use clean or boiled water.
Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before cooking and after feeding.
In addition to breastfeeding, feed the baby 3 times a day (2 meals and 1 oatmeal), one glass of tea (125 ml) different food and 1 meal.\n Fruits can be included in the lunch\n
Discourage eating less nutritious food available in the market.\n It will make your child less healthy\n
In addition to breastfeeding, 3 times a day (3 meals only), two teaspoons of glass (250 ml) of supplementary food and 2 meals should be fed.

Each meal should include the three food groups.
 Snacks should include seasonal fruits and eggs if possible. Beans are also good for snack.
 Eating fresh home-cooked food (meat, eggs and fish) should be encouraged.
